articles.headline: No Shortcuts When Military Moves a War
articles.snippet: The movement of U.S. forces from Iraq to Afghanistan is one of the largest such operations since World War II.
articles.abstract: The movement of U.S. forces from Iraq to Afghanistan is one of the largest such operations since World War II.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOINT BASE BALAD, Iraq — Early this year a “fob in a box” — military slang for 80 shipping containers with all the tents, showers and construction material needed to set up a remote forward operating base — was put on trucks here for the trip from one war to another.
articles.byline: By Stephen Farrell and Elisabeth Bumiller

articles.headline: Looking at the iPad From Two Angles
articles.snippet: Apple’s iPad seems to be hated by techies and loved by everyone else. Here are separate reviews for the two audiences.
articles.abstract: Apple’s iPad seems to be hated by techies and loved by everyone else. Here are separate reviews for the two audiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 10 years of reviewing tech products for The New York Times, I’ve never seen a product as polarizing as Apple’s iPad, which arrives in stores on Saturday.

articles.headline: Successes (and Some Growing Pains) at Hulu
articles.snippet: Hulu has brought television watching on the Web into the mainstream, but it is coming under increasing pressure from the companies that supply its content.
articles.abstract: Hulu has brought television watching on the Web into the mainstream, but it is coming under increasing pressure from the companies that supply its content.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hulu, the popular and free online video hub, has some things to celebrate as it heads into its third year.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Rushed From Haiti, Then Jailed for Lacking Visas
articles.snippet: At least 30 earthquake survivors are prisoners of the U.S. immigration system, locked up since arriving in Florida.
articles.abstract: At least 30 earthquake survivors are prisoners of the U.S. immigration system, locked up since arriving in Florida.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than two months after the earthquake that devastated Haiti, at least 30 survivors who were waved onto planes by Marines in the chaotic aftermath are prisoners of the United States immigration system, locked up since their arrival in detention centers in Florida.

articles.headline: Risk Is Clear in Drilling; Payoff Isn’t
articles.snippet: President Obama set out to attract bipartisan support and increase oil production, but the plan may not do either.
articles.abstract: President Obama set out to attract bipartisan support and increase oil production, but the plan may not do either.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In proposing a major expansion of offshore oil and gas development, President Obama set out to fashion a carefully balanced plan that would attract bipartisan support for climate and energy legislation while increasing production of domestic oil.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Pay of Hedge Fund Managers Roared Back Last Year
articles.snippet: With the recovery of big banks, the top 25 hedge fund managers took home an average of $1 billion in 2009.
articles.abstract: With the recovery of big banks, the top 25 hedge fund managers took home an average of $1 billion in 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Lazarus-like recovery of the nation’s big banks did not benefit just the bankers — it also created huge paydays for hedge fund managers, including a record $4 billion gain in 2009 for one bold investor who bet big on the financial sector.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Louise Story

articles.headline: Pfizer Chief Says Growth Is Imminent
articles.snippet: Producing new drugs and adjusting to the changing health care system are two of the tests facing the drug giant.
articles.abstract: Producing new drugs and adjusting to the changing health care system are two of the tests facing the drug giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world’s largest drug company, Pfizer, has handled mergers badly, invented too few drugs and left its reputation in disrepair after two criminal cases.

articles.headline: Deadlock Is Ending on Labor Board
articles.snippet: The National Labor Relations Board will soon have three Democrats and one Republican, and businesses are bracing for a wave of pro-union rulings.
articles.abstract: The National Labor Relations Board will soon have three Democrats and one Republican, and businesses are bracing for a wave of pro-union rulings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Because of President Obama’s recess appointments of two union lawyers to the National Labor Relations Board, business groups are warning that the panel will kick quickly into a pro-union gear after 26 months of near paralysis, when just two of its five seats were filled.

articles.headline: Amid Thaw, Obama Talks With Chinese Leader
articles.snippet: President Obama and President Hu Jintao spoke for an hour by phone and expressed a desire for healthier ties.
articles.abstract: President Obama and President Hu Jintao spoke for an hour by phone and expressed a desire for healthier ties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tensions between China and the United States have ebbed significantly in recent days, with the countries now working together to deter Iran’s nuclear ambitions and with the Obama administration backing off a politically charged clash over China’s currency.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Andrew Jacobs
